body.p: Ioanna Bakopoulou is a senior research fellow for the Centre for Educational Development, Appraisal and Research at the University of Warwick, UK. Her main research interests are in socio-emotional functioning of children with SLI. She is also interested in elements supporting communication within the classroom and developing language rich classroom environments.

Dorothy Bishop is a psychologist funded by the Wellcome Trust to run a programme of research investigating children’s language impairments. She is a Fellow of the British Academy, and a Fellow of the Academy of Medical Sciences, and an Honorary Fellow of the Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists.

Becky Clark is RALLI’s editor and a speech and language therapist working independently in Surrey with children with SLI and other communication difficulties. She also works at Moor House School in Oxted and has previously worked in research at The Institute of Education and The National Hospital’s College of Speech Sciences (now UCL).

Gina Conti-Ramsden is a speech and language therapist with particular interest in specific language impairment (SLI). She is Professor of Child Language and Learning at the University of Manchester, UK and Director of the well-known longitudinal study of SLI (The Manchester Language Study) which has been running in England since 1995, following children with SLI from the age of 7 years to adulthood. She is a Fellow of the Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists, a Fellow of the British Psychological Society and an Academician of the Social Sciences.

Mikenzi Ford is a speech-language pathology graduate student at Utah State University, USA. Her research interests center around preschool age children with language deficits, specifically in phonological awareness and pre-literacy skills. She received funding as an undergraduate from Utah State to conduct portions of this research project.

Sandra Laing Gillam is a Professor at Utah State University in the Emma Eccles Jones Early Childhood Education and Research Center in Logan, Utah, USA. Her research interests include assessment and intervention of language and literacy for children with language-based learning problems, discourse comprehension and culturally and linguistically diverse populations.

Laura B. Green is an assistant professor at Texas Woman’s University, USA. Her research interests include narrative intervention, treatment research for children with language/learning difficulties, and the contribution of morphological awareness to children’s literacy skills.

Joni S. Klecan-Aker is a retired Full Professor who currently works in private practice in Fort Worth, Texas, USA. She has authored numerous articles detailing her research with primary and secondary students with language/learning difficulties. Her specific research interests include narrative assessment and intervention, evidence-based practice, and curriculum-based instruction.

Geoff Lindsay is Professor of Educational Psychology and Special Needs Education at the University of Warwick, UK where he is Director of the Centre for Educational Development, Appraisal and Research (CEDAR). Research interests include practice and policy for children and young people with speech, language and communication needs.

Maria Mroz is a lecturer in education working on a primary postgraduate course. Her research interests include the understandings that early years practitioners have about children with SLCN and the impact of changes to the primary curriculum for literacy.

Courtenay Norbury directs the Literacy, Language and Communication (LiLaC) Lab at Royal Holloway, University of London (www.pc.rhul.ac.uk/sites/lilac) . She is also a speech-language therapist and leads the Surrey Communication and Language in Education Study (SCALES), the first UK population study of risk for language delay at school entry.

Michelle Pascoe is a senior lecturer in the Department of Health and Rehabilitation Sciences, University of Cape Town, South Africa. She is a speech and language therapist with a particular interest in intervention, and the application of psycholinguistic frameworks to understanding children with speech and literacy difficulties.

Christina Reuterskiöld is an associate professor in the Department of Communicative Sciences and Disorders at New York University, USA, where she teaches courses and conducts research in language development, language disorders and literacy learning in children. She holds degrees from Boston University, USA and Lund University in Sweden.

Sue Roulstone is the Underwood Trust Professor of Language and Communication Impairment at the University of the West of England, Bristol, UK. She is also a director of the Bristol Speech and Language Therapy Research Unit and North Bristol NHS Trust, UK. Research interests include children and family perspectives on speech and language impairment, professional judgement and decision-making, epidemiology of speech and language impairment, evaluation of speech and language therapy.

Diana Van Lancker Sidtis is Professor of Communicative Sciences and Disorders at New York University, USA and Associate Director of the Brain and Behavior Laboratory. Her education included the University of Chicago, USA, Brown University, USA and an NIH Postdoctoral Fellowship. She teaches and performs neurolinguistic and speech science research.

Maggie Snowling is President of St John’s College, The University of Oxford, UK, and is a Chartered Clinical Psychologist. She served on Sir Jim Rose’s Expert Advisory Group on provision for Dyslexia (2009) and was an expert member of the Education for All: Fast Track Initiative group in Washington, DC, USA (2011).

Jane Speake is a speech and language therapist who manages the speech and language therapy service for children in Cambridgeshire, UK and works with children who have severe speech difficulties. She is the author of several speech and language resources including ‘How to identify and support children with speech and language difficulties’ (2003, LDA). Jane is currently working towards her PhD at the University of Sheffield, UK.

Joy Stackhouse is Professor of Human Communication Sciences at the University of Sheffield, UK. She is a Fellow of the Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists and a chartered psychologist. Along with Professor Bill Wells, she has developed a psycholinguistic approach to the assessment and management of children with speech and literacy difficulties, which is used in research and practice.

Yvonne Wren is a senior research speech and language therapist at Bristol Speech and Language Therapy Research Unit, UK and a Visiting Research Fellow at the University of the West of England, UK. Her work on the Better Communication Research Programme has focused on identifying the range of interventions offered nationally for children with SLCN.
